Line 28: Line 28:      
===Chemistry of love===
 
===Chemistry of love===
−
:''See main: [[Interpersonal chemistry]] and [[human chemistry]].''
+
:''See main: [[Interpersonal chemistry]].''
−   −
[[Image:HC-Cover-VI-3-inch.jpg|150px|thumb|right|Front cover of 2007 book ''Human Chemistry (Volume One)'' by American [[chemical engineer]] Libb Thims in which '''love''' is viewed as a purely [[human chemistry|chemical reaction]].<ref name="HCI" >{{cite book | last = Thims | first = Libb | title = [http://www.lulu.com/content/1026825 Human Chemistry (Volume One)] | publisher = LuLu | year = 2007 | id = ISBN 978-1-4303-1049-5}}</ref><ref name="HCII" >{{cite book | last = Thims | first = Libb | title = [http://www.lulu.com/content/1165688 Human Chemistry (Volume Two)] | publisher = LuLu | year = 2007 | id = ISBN 978-1-4303-2840-7}}</ref><ref>[http://www.humanthermodynamics.com/RP5-Love-Chemical-Reaction.html Is Love a Chemical Reaction?] - Institute of Human Thermodynamics</ref>]]
       
Biological models of sex tend to view love as a [[mammal]]ian drive, much like [[hunger]] or [[thirst]].<ref>{{cite book | last = Lewis | first = Thomas | coauthors = Amini, F., & Lannon, R. | title = A General Theory of Love | publisher = Random House | year = 2000 | id = ISBN 0-375-70922-3}}</ref> [[Helen Fisher (anthropologist)|Helen Fisher]], a leading expert in the topic of love, divides the experience of love into three partly-overlapping stages: lust, attraction, and attachment. Lust exposes people to others, romantic attraction encourages people to focus their energy on mating, and attachment involves tolerating the spouse long enough to rear a child into infancy.
 
Biological models of sex tend to view love as a [[mammal]]ian drive, much like [[hunger]] or [[thirst]].<ref>{{cite book | last = Lewis | first = Thomas | coauthors = Amini, F., & Lannon, R. | title = A General Theory of Love | publisher = Random House | year = 2000 | id = ISBN 0-375-70922-3}}</ref> [[Helen Fisher (anthropologist)|Helen Fisher]], a leading expert in the topic of love, divides the experience of love into three partly-overlapping stages: lust, attraction, and attachment. Lust exposes people to others, romantic attraction encourages people to focus their energy on mating, and attachment involves tolerating the spouse long enough to rear a child into infancy.
